feed.title: Combined summary - Anti-transaction replay in a hardfork

entry.title: Combined summary - Anti-transaction replay in a hardfork
entry.summary: In discussions among developers, proposals have been made to prevent transaction replay attacks in the event of a chain split. One proposed solution involves creating a “bridge” that replays all transactions from one network over to the other, ensuring that a fork is transparent to end-users. Another proposal involves changing the validation algorithm to require a unique child transaction on each network, effectively preventing replay attacks. Johnson Lau proposed an opt-out approach to anti-replay, while Tom Harding suggested a soft fork that supports its own hard-fork opt-out bit. The proposals have various objectives and limitations, including the inability to protect transactions made before the proposal and the need for hardfork proposals to consider the harmful effects of replay attacks. Developers have also discussed changes to the sighash algorithm as part of a hard fork, with compatibility with existing transaction-signing software and hardware being an important consideration.Developers have discussed the idea of changing the sighash as part of a hard fork in order to prevent replay attacks on both networks. However, backward compatibility is necessary and old-format transactions could still be valid when paired with a fork-only follow-up transaction. This introduces new statefulness into the block validation logic but is necessary for maximal fork safety. The old network should also soft-fork in an identical rule with a follow-up transaction format incompatible with the fork to prevent old transactions from being replayed across forks/networks because they're not valid when stand-alone. Wallet clients would need to be updated or paired with software that intercepts generated transactions and automatically generates the correct follow-up transaction for it (old network only).There was also a proposal to require a unique child transaction on each network that would be necessary for the transaction to be valid. By implementing this policy change simultaneously in both networks, old pre-signed transactions could only be replayed by the owner of the coins, as they would have to spend them immediately in the child transaction. Once spent, the UTXO sets would diverge across the two networks, effectively preventing replay attacks.During a blockchain split, replay attacks can occur when transactions are replayed on another network. The proposal suggests creating a "bridge" that replays all transactions from one network over to the other and vice-versa to prevent this issue. The proposal also recommends making anti-replay optional and not mandatory for users on both existing and new forks. Transactions created before the proposal will not be protected from anti-replay. No consensus changes are required in the existing network to avoid unnecessary debate. Additionally, the O(n^2) signature checking bug could be fixed for non-segregated witness inputs optionally. The proposal has limitations, including being unable to protect transactions made before the proposal, and it is up to the designer of a hardfork to decide whether to respect this proposal.In discussions on the bitcoin-dev mailing list, concerns were raised about anti-replay during hardforks. Some members suggested limiting transactions on the UTXO chain from before a fork to maximize chain divergence, but Gavin Andresen argued that compatibility with existing transaction signing software and hardware should also be considered. He believes that any hard fork proposal should support a reasonable number of reasonable-size old-sighash transactions to allow for smooth transitions of wallet software and hardware.There were also email exchanges between developers discussing the potential for a hard fork to create two incompatible ledgers. Priest suggested creating a "bridge" that replays all transactions from one network over to the other to prevent confusion for end-users. The goal should be unity rather than permanent division.Overall, these conversations highlight the importance of preventing transaction replay attacks in case of a chain split and the need to ensure backward compatibility. The pre-BIP proposal addresses these issues while minimizing changes to the existing network. The longer both forks persist, the more transactions become unavoidably fork-specific through the mixing in of new post-fork coins. Upgraded software can create transactions guaranteed not to execute to one fork or the other, or that are not prevented from execution on either fork. This would result in much less chaotic markets and well-determined prices for the two currencies. However, none of this precludes the possibility of further forks on either side, and the difficulty consideration alone suggests a likely counter-fork by (part of) the existing network.In another email exchange between developers, a misunderstanding about their proposals for a new network design arose. Lau proposed an opt-in system, while Harding's proposal was opt-out. Upon realizing the difference, Harding expressed concern that Lau's proposal would require modifications to already compatible systems, making it unlikely to be included in new network designs. However, Lau clarified that their proposals were essentially the same, with the only difference being the use of a bitwise not before the network characteristic byte. This clarification led Harding to agree that an opt-out system would make more sense for everyone involved.These discussions focus on the technical details of network design and hardfork proposals, particularly related to preventing replay attacks during blockchain splits.
